lead_paragraph: Can regular games of bridge or chess or playing a musical instrument ward off the onset of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia? abstract: THEISE--Lee (nee Weiss). On October 9, 2003. Widow of Henry. Beloved mother of Joyce Jonas and Richard Theise, grandmother of Jillian Jonas, Stephanie Jonas Stone and Peter Theise, great - grandmother of Charles Kamuti Stone, sister of Stanley Weiss, mother-inlaw of Marti Theise and Gilbert Jonas. Lee was born in Poland and her family left for Palestine in 1933. In 1938 she went to New York City with her father for the World's Fair and was joined by the balance of the family shortly thereafter. She was a member of the Standard Club and the Ahavath Achim Congregation in Atlanta until her husband Henry's death in 1979 and of Temple Emanuel in West Palm Beach for the remainder of her life. She was an active supporter of the Simon Wiesenthal Foundation, ORT, the Jabotinsky Library in Tel Aviv and of several other charities. Lee was an extraordinary woman and will be remembered by all who knew her. The funeral will take place in Atlanta on Tuesday, October 14. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Institute for Brain Aging and Dementia.

abstract: Judge Elliot Solomon rules that Leslie Andino, 23, is mentally incompetent to stand trial for starting fire in Hartford nursing home that killed 16 residents; Andino will receive psychiatric evalutation and will be evaluated in two months (S)
snippet: Judge Elliot Solomon rules that Leslie Andino, 23, is mentally incompetent to stand trial for starting fire in Hartford nursing home that killed 16 residents; Andino will receive psychiatric evalutation and will be evaluated in two months (S)
lead_paragraph: A woman accused of setting a nursing-home fire that led to the deaths of 16 residents, many of them severely disabled, is incompetent to stand trial, a judge ruled yesterday. A Hartford Superior Court judge, Elliot Solomon, ruled that the woman, Leslie Andino, 23, suffers from dementia and depression. After a psychiatric evaluation, Ms. Andino is to undergo further treatment at Connecticut Valley Hospital and will be evaluated again in two months. Ms. Andino told the police that she might have accidentally started the February fire at the Greenwood Health Center while playing with a cigarette lighter. But an investigation later determined that a lighter would have had to be held under sheets for at least 30 seconds to start a fire. Marc Santora (NYT)

abstract: BERG-Seymour, M.D. 4/3/2110/12/02. Seymour Berg, M.D. died on October 12, 2002 at Grosvenor Park Nursing Home in Salem, MA, after a long illness. He was born on April 3, 1921 in the Bronx, to Gustave Berg and Anna Levine Berg. He graduated in 1937 from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, received a B.A. from N.Y.U. College of Arts and Science in 1941, and obtained a medical degree from N.Y.U. School of Medicine in 1945. After an internship at City Hospital on Welfare Island, he served as 1st Lieutenant and then Captain in the Army Medical Corps AUS, at the V.A. Hospital in Sheridan, WY, where he met his future wife of 33 years, Margaret Irene (Peggy) Walden. Dr. Berg did his residency in psychiatry at Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, and remained on staff there for over 30 years, ultimately serving as Psychiatric Unit Chief of Ward No. 6 for many years. During that time, he also taught at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine and Hunter College-Bellevue School of Nursing, and maintained a part-time private practice. Dr. Berg served as Honorary Surgeon in Psychiatry to the New York City Police Department and Consulting Psychiatrist to the Triboro Bridge & Tunnel Authority and The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Dr. Berg was a member of the American, New York and Massachusetts Medical Associations, a member and Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, a member of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease and the Society of Biological Psychiatry, and a Diplomate Member and Member of the Council of the Section on Psychiatry & Neurology of the Pan American Medical Association. He also served on the editorial board of the medical journal ''Behavioral Neuropsychiatry''. Dr. Berg was most proud of his teaching and his early research on electroshock therapy. Dr. Berg and his wife Peggy raised their four children in Lake Success, New York, where they lived for 28 years. Peggy predeceased him in 1981; he was later married for several years to Florence Preschel. He was an avid power boater, and was active for many years in the Sands Point Yacht Club (serving as Commodore in 1975), and the Bayshore Power Squadron. Dr. Berg is survived by his daughters Deborah Berg of Seattle, WA, Sherry Berg of Newburyport, MA, Mary Moreau of Waterbury, CT, his son G. David Walden-Berg of Oakland, CA, his brother Sheldon (Buddy) Berg of Northvale, NJ, grandchildren Tyler Fey, Cooper Neal, Hannah Moreau and Esther Moreau, nieces Eileen Berg and nephews Gary Berg, Gerald Berg and Jeffrey Berg. A private service was held and, at his request, his ashes will be strewn in the Long Island Sound. The family requests that any memorial donations be made to the N.Y.U. School of Medicine Office of Development, specifying that the funds be used for research relating to strokes or dementia.

lead_paragraph: Anubile blonde squats on her boyfriend's bare chest and he's too stoned to do much about it. Nipple clamps? No sir, not this time. Even one would just be, like, way generous. Seizing him by the neck with both hands, she raises her shins from the carpet and presses her full dead weight onto his rib cage and solar plexus, forcing more air from his lungs. How's that feel? As she rocks back and forth, they lock eyes. "You like that?" she asks, flirty as ever. "How come?" Her name is Sandra Murphy. When she wears clothes, her taste runs to Gucci, Victoria's Secret, Versace. Her latest ride is the SL 500, in black. She used to work at a high-end sports car emporium in Long Beach, so she knows what the good stuff is. After that gig she moved to Las Vegas and danced topless professionally, but she hasn't had to work in three years-not since she danced for the guy she is currently laying her hands on. "My old man," she calls him sometimes, or "my husband," especially since she moved in. And she would sort of like to get married. Settle down, kids, that whole deal. Not right now, though. Because you, you've got time , as Liz Phair advises in "Polyester Bride," one of Sandy's all-time favorite songs. Time to get rich, see the world, party hearty. And lately she's been having the time of her used-to-be-not-so-great life. Million-dollar mansion, cute boyfriend, bionic sex, Benz, plus she's keeping her looks, above all. That's the key. In 1989 she was runner-up for the title of Miss Bellflower, a south-central suburb of Los Angeles. That was nine years ago, when Sandy was seventeen, but she maintains her dancer's physique by working out five days a week, and she still keeps the sash in her closet. Most men, her boyfriend included, cannot get enough of her, especially the way she looks now. She is lithe, wet, determined, on top.

lead_paragraph: Alice lived in her great-aunt's large bungalow on Wren Street in a desirable neighborhood known as Los Feliz. A hundred and fifty years before, Corporal Jose Vicente Feliz was awarded a Spanish land grant for his role in civilizing the unruly new pueblo of Los Angeles. Rancho Los Feliz-or the Happy Farm as it was often called-was a small, wealthy fiefdom with two thousand acres of mountainous wooded terrain teeming with game, a thousand more in flat arable fields and pastureland, and several miles of riverbed. Corporal Feliz enjoyed this windfall for eight short years. His savvy widow, Dona Verdugo, remarried and held on for decades, establishing legal title to the land once Mexico gained independence from Spain. Her heirs were less tenacious; several daughters sold their holdings at a dollar per acre, and the primary heir, Antonio, bequeathed his major holding to the family lawyer.
